comments.body: I'd love to see this implemented. There have been multiple times in the past when I've wanted to customize the item tooltips, but have been unable to because that graphic is hardcoded.
I think it could easily be accomplished with a single texture split into its 9 components, and also an mcmeta file describing whether to stretch the components, tile them, or both.

It's possible to do via core shaders, so it's not impossible with a resource pack, however it should be a texture in my opinion, since that'd open a whole new world for the people who don't know how to even edit core shaders.

I really like this idea. It might be difficult to blend the two different types of lighting, but I think that the soulfire torches look off when they emit normal yellow tinted light.

Integrate the new lighting in other light sources aswell!
Sea lanterns should have this too, and glow squids should create greenish light (the yellowish light surrounding them looks awful), and lava should create red light.
i'd love to see anything soulfire actually have blue lighting, it's so jarring to see a blue flame give off yellow/orange glows
Neat idea, actually. Voted.
I have always wanted a whole set of underwater noises, things like droppers and dispensers should make a different shooting sound

I use Intel graphics 2000. On windows drivers only go up to opengl 3.1 but on linux they go up to 3.3 which makes it possible to play 1.17+.

Hi all. I understand why you're all frustrated, but I just learned Minecraft did this and I want to explain why this is one of the BIGGEST improvements to Minecraft in a long time. OpenGL 3.2 came out about the time Minecraft was originally being developed. Minecraft was using legacy technology from day one. Over the years, the benefits of this newer technology has been completely inaccessible to Minecraft, those who make mods, etc.

 

It is certainly a rough loss for those who are unable to play anymore, but it would be too difficult to maintain two separate rendering pipelines just for people who have computers that don't support 10 year old graphics standards.

 

The benefits this brings is absolutely immense, it will open up many possibilities for shaders in the vanilla game, the possibilities are really endless. I can understand the frustration with this, but I understand the technology behind this, and I promise this is 100% the right decision for the game.

I also understand the technology behind this, and I see 0 benefit for the game from switch to 3.3. Modern Minecraft requires GL 4.5. Shaders are available since OpenGL 2.0, and the ancient pipeline was basically deprecated then, if not in 1.5. Rendering of Minecraft is extremely simple and does not require features even from 15 years ago. And what isn't simple, like shaders, are still available since 2.0, and were part of OptiFine for a while now.
But, perhaps Minecraft developers are now utilizing those new features for the betterment of player experience? Let's see. They haven't added native shader customization, it still requires mods, so that's that... The game also runs slower than it did 5 years ago... Graphics look the same, just with better textures (which don't require a newer API)... And now a bunch of old machines cannot even run newer versions of Minecraft at all because their drivers weren't updates in a while. I'd call it a win! For the kingdom of satan, of course.

It would be a win win but the people who are not able to do anything what about them they are stuck on 1.16.5 till now 1.20 has been released so more than 50,000 Minecraft players have not experienced the new upgrades 

me myself noticed that Minecraft started to die when 1.17 was released as many players were not able to play the game
